image.altText: A woman wearing a white head scarf glances down towards her hands

items.synopsis: When Israeli air strikes began near their home, Hana' Nayem and her family decided to flee on foot. She and more than 20 relatives have taken shelter elsewhere, but right now, nowhere in Gaza is safe.

title.children: 'Sitting here in horror': The flat with no door, and twenty-five people sheltering inside

image.altText: Fire crews stand in front of an overturned bus beside a road.

items.synopsis: The review was conducted after the Hunter Valley bus crash that killed 10 people earlier this year. The NSW government has vowed to implement all five of the recommendations made and will launch a new seatbelt safety campaign immediately.

title.children: Safety report issued after tragic wedding party bus crash that shocked the nation

image.altText: Two police officers at an event

items.synopsis: More than 23,000 people were caught up in the court system for small quantity drug possession last year, a new policy of on-the-spot fines aims to reduce that, but experts say it doesn't go far enough.

title.children: New drug laws in NSW a 'double-edged sword', legal expert warns

image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal

image.altText: Black letters that spell out PwC on a white wall with red, orange and yellow graphic squares above the letter C.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant PwC is accused of misleading the Senate after revelations it planned to sell its consultancy business at the same time it pushed back against the idea in evidence to a separate inquiry in 2019.

title.children: PwC caught out after telling Senate it was against 'separating' its businesses while looking for a seller in private

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

items.synopsis: As an Aboriginal person, it feels impossible to digest the freight train of messages coming towards us each day. Most of it is about us, without us, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: Elders say the racism of this year is some of the worst they've seen. Indigenous people deserve so much more

image.altText: Thick black and grey smoke rises above multistorey buildings following an airstrike.

items.synopsis: Fears are widening that the Israel-Gaza conflict could spread further and create more volatility for investors and the global economy, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

image.altText: A grahpic of coloured question marks surrounding a black and white photo of parliament house.

items.synopsis: One of Australia's leading constitutional law experts believes the Voice referendum could be the last time Australians vote to change the constitution, after more than 12 months of campaigning from both sides of politics.

title.children: Constitutional expert believes Voice vote could be the last referendum held in Australia

image.altText: Ripe fresh fruit, lemons, green and red apples in a shop

items.synopsis: Retail fruit prices have barely changed in two decades, exports have dropped to about two per cent of the nation's crop and producers are fleeing the industry, new data from a NSW Farmers Association survey reveals.

title.children: Apple farmers exit industry after pocketing a rise of just 50c a kilo in 20 years

image.altText: Mitchell Starc lays on the ground.

items.synopsis: Six dropped catches and some inept batting leaves Australia with a 0-2 record at the Cricket World Cup.

title.children: Aussies grass six catches in humiliating defeat to South Africa at Cricket World Cup

image.altText: A purple-blue backlit desk featuring multiple people playing games on keyboards.

items.synopsis: What are the climate consequences of developing video games? When an independent studio made its sixth game, it decided to find out.

title.children: 'No video games on a dead planet': New report reveals carbon cost of game development

image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: A view of a narrow underground tunnel.

items.synopsis: An Israeli invasion of Gaza will face an enemy that has built a formidable armoury, dug a vast tunnel network to evade attackers and shown in past ground wars it can exact a heavier toll on Israeli troops each time.

title.children: To defeat Hamas the Israeli military will likely have to conquer tunnels they call the 'Gaza metro'

image.altText: Two trucks and a tank, in the desert, with mounds of earth for cover

items.synopsis: Israel's army says its campaign against Hamas is aimed at "taking out" the terror group's senior leadership including top government officials.

title.children: Israel prepares for 'ground manoeuvre' against Hamas

image.altText: A porcupine using its spikes to defend itself against a leopard

items.synopsis: An image of a mysterious, shimmering golden horseshoe crab, one of almost 50,000 entries from 95 countries, takes first place in the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition.

title.children: Fighting goats and a hippo nursery: The winning images from the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition

image.altText: A plane flying towards the sun.

items.synopsis: Aviation emissions have almost doubled since 2000 and in 2018 reached 1 billion tonnes. Climate Action Tracker rates the industry's climate performance as critically insufficient, despite the fact Australian airlines are introducing newer, more fuel efficient aircraft into their fleets.

title.children: Flying less and charging more are ways to reduce airlines' carbon emissions, but would travellers get on board?

image.altText: An outback setting

items.synopsis: A decrease in the quality of phosphate being mined overseas and growing investor interest in ethical projects are driving miners into Australia's largely untapped reserves.

title.children: Mining to begin on Australia's biggest phosphate deposits amid global demand for fertiliser

image.altText: A man with long hair and a beard carrying a plastic bag

items.synopsis: Police charge a 23-year-old man with intimidation after four teens were allegedly threatened for displaying an Israeli flag across their car in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: Minister calls man's alleged threat to teens who were displaying Israeli flag 'anti-Semitic'

image.altText: A map of the world showing Australia on the right and Africa on the left, and yellow and blue representing water temperatures

items.synopsis: One of the main drivers behind Australia's year to year rainfall and temperature variability is approaching levels not seen since the summer of 2019.

title.children: Southern states sizzle as Indian Ocean climate driver nears record strength

image.altText: A blister pack of the antibiotic doxycycline, which is used to treat a range of conditions from acne to cholera.

items.synopsis: Australia's leading sexual health experts say taking a drug known as "doxy-PEP" after unprotected sex could help curb rising rates of syphilis, but there's a big catch associated with antibiotic use.

title.children: There's a new kind of 'morning after' pill on the scene. But it's not to prevent pregnancies

image.altText: two firefighters looking at burnt ground

items.synopsis: Residents in five regions, including Greater Sydney, are being told to stay alert ahead of the hot and windy conditions forecast for today. The fire risk is rated as high for much of the rest of the state.

title.children: Schools closed, extreme fire danger warnings issued across NSW as South Coast blaze burns on

image.altText: Jim Everett

items.synopsis: Aboriginal activist Jimmy Everett-Puralia Meenamatta doesn't believe the Voice would result in meaningful change for First Nations people. Instead, he'd prefer to see a treaty.

title.children: Why I'd prefer treaty instead of the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A man in a hat and Yes t-shirt holds a young child with a Yes campaign flag in the background

items.synopsis: Two days out from the Voice referendum, Noel Pearson is urging voters to think of future generations as they head to the polling booths.

title.children: 'The politicians have vandalised this': Voice co-architect issues last pitch before referendum

image.altText: A range of olive oils sit on a supermarket shelf.

items.synopsis: The largest producer of olive oil in Australia says it is delighted by the support it is getting from Australian consumers as prices for international competitors rise.

title.children: How Aussie extra-virgin olive oil is bucking an international trend

image.altText: Three Hezbolah flags fluttering above a poster depicting Lebanon's Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah

items.synopsis: Here's what you need to know about Hezbollah and its role in the Israel-Hamas conflict.

title.children: What is Hezbollah and what happens if it gets involved in the Israel-Hamas conflict?

image.altText: SCAM duo

items.synopsis: A regional bank manager and her staff stepped in when an elderly local couple were being swindled by brazen scammers to the tune of $10,000.

title.children: 'It all looked unnatural': Small-town bank saves couple from losing $10,000 to brazen scammers

image.altText: Vanessa Amorosi getting into a car

items.synopsis: The singer-songwriter broke down as she told the court her mother convinced her not to trust anyone with her millions at the height of her career.

title.children: Vanessa Amorosi breaks down in court and says a property dispute with her mother started a family 'war'

image.altText: Two female netball players jump for the ball under the net, with another player to the side

items.synopsis: The Diamonds shrug off a week dominated by the Super Netball pay dispute to beat New Zealand by 10 points.

title.children: Diamonds open Constellation Cup series with win over Silver Ferns

image.altText: Three images spliced together show Chance the Rapper on stage, Nicole Kidman in movie Australia and Charlie Brooker.

items.synopsis: In its world-first debut outside of Austin, Texas, groundbreaking festival South by Southwest is coming to Sydney. But with tickets going for up to $1,895 how do locals get involved?

title.children: Flying cars and film stars: The 'Olympics of Festivals' lands in Sydney next week

image.altText: Two panda cubs, sitting in a basket, in front of a sign with their names.

items.synopsis: South Koreans get their first close look at a new pair of baby giant pandas at a name-revealing ceremony.

title.children: 'Cuter in real life': South Korea names its twin pandas 97 days after their birth

image.altText: Man sits at a piano and plays

items.synopsis: In the era of reboots, it's time for Frasier to have his moment, here's what we thought.

title.children: Frasier is back — here's what you need to know about the reboot
